reviews.review_title: Tedius, Fulfilling- A standard Tarkovski Odyssey
reviews.content: Most viewers should think twice before trying to watch this film. It is not a story so much as a series of scenes recalled by memory- i.e. fuzzy, disjointed, and sentimentalised while still being personal. To say the film has a plot or story- per se- would be misguiding. Asking what purpose it does have is probably fairly misguided, as well. Like scenes from our own life, the scenes in this film just happen to us and we are the higher intelligence responsible for imposing order and specifying why they have happened or what they signify.Like impressionism in painting, Tarkovski's objective is to create works that directly interact with the human mind's tendency to convert symbols into emotion. The experiences and environment of Andrei Rublev's life is crafted for us by Tarkovski. The cruelty, hardship, and frank confusion of his life is patiently rendered by Tarkovski in his impressionistic style that seems oblique to "conventional" cinematic sensibilities but which is remarkably direct about evoking the desired emotional response. The film is replete with remarkable scenes- the balloon flight that opens the movie and the casting of the great church bell being two of the most memorable. The latter could be construed as either the power of an individual's vision or as what anyone can do when God wills it. Either interpretation would have inspired the creative efforts of any artist.Obviously, some cross-comparison with his other films should be in order. Solyaris (1972), his cult Science Fiction masterpiece is a marginally inferior film that still manages to be, for me, more satisfying because of my sentimental romantic tendencies that allow me to overlook the disjointed plot, poor editing in a few scenes, and the occasionally wooden or otherwise unconvincing dialogue. Andrei Rublev is better in most of these respects and is well photographed on a fairly consistent stock of Black-and-White film. Black and white definitely suit the movie, too- colour would have given the scenes too much "presence" and made them seem more mundane- black and white help preserve a sense of reverie. In both films, there is not great sense of urgency and scenes play out in their own (occasionally tedious) pace. Both films feel much more spontaneous to me than Tarkovski's last work- "Sacrifice" starring the great Erland Josephson and this seeming artlessness gives them a vitality that this last film lacks.In conclusion- this is a fine Tarkovski film. It is as good a film as any of his for introducing new viewers. Viewers should approach it with the proper mindset, however. Their objective should be to experience the film and their reaction to it. Obviously, interest in Russia around the 13th century will probably not hurt appreciation. While the film is, in its totality, different from most films, the individual scenes are not weird- no strange camera work, no sudden introduction of esoteric symbols, just fairly honest attempts to record an individual person's impression of what viewers today might find to be unusual experiences.

Spoilers herein.Andrei Rublyov is a meditation on the meaning and power of art in dark times.  Ultimately does art have any power of it¡¯s own?  Is it only a distraction for the powerful or does it have the power to create enduring transcendence?The questions asked by the film also relate to the film¡¯s production. Tarkovsky, the enigmatic and ambitious Russian director wanted to create a film about the spiritual dimension of the creative process.  The Russian government of the time only wanted Marxist propaganda.  The parallel could not be clearer Andrei a Russian Icon painter wants to create art but is prevented by the political chaos of the fifteenth century.  Tarkovsky wants to create authentic cinematic art but is prevented by the communist regime in power in the twentieth century.  Both men are dedicated to living in harmony with values outside or the times that they live in.The film is mostly in black and white, but switch to color at the end when we are treated to a splendid display of the paintings that Andrei went on to create despite his hardships.  Up until then the film has been little more then a disconnected series of episodes, each with a precise but obscure meaning, the overall point being that Andrei cannot create in a world so full of suffering.In the films final sequence, Andrei encounters a young boy who is trying to get a group of laborers to build a church bell.  In this act he is trying to follow in his father¡¯s footsteps.  After much bullying and cajoling they build the bell and it works perfectly.  The boy breaks down in tears.  He confesses that his father in fact did not teach him the secret of building the bell, he was merely ¡°winging it¡± out of a shear desperate desire to create.This description, however only scratches the movie¡¯s surface.  Lovingly photographed, each frame looks like it could be a painting by itself. There are cold barren Russian landscapes, ecstatic pagan orgies, and elaborate church interiors.  This is a film unafraid to deal with big difficult themes.  In intellectual content and shear artfulness Andrei Rublyov is unmatched. 10/10

I have now seen most of Andrei Tarkovsky's fine films including Ivan's Childhood and Nostalghia. The sci-fi masterpiece Solaris was surprisingly my least favourite and I enjoyed Steven Soderbergh's take on the famous Plish noel better. The fact that I didn't quite enjoy Tarkovsky's original film as much at first viewing may also mean I need to revisit it like Villeneuve's Arrival I appreciated much more the second time. In any case, as it stands Stalker and The Mirror were my favourite Tarkovsky movies until I finally got through the long 205 minutes if Andrei Rublev.Andrei Rublev is not the best painter biopic ever made, Frida (2002), Mr Tuner (2014), Lust for Life (1956) or the 210min Edvard Munch (1974) would be better.Andrei Rublev is however much more than a movie about a painter or painting. Instead, it paints a painful and powerful portrait of life of the fifteenth-century, Middle Ages or medieval period in Europe, which we now sometimes refer to as the Dark Ages. Russians were fighting with Tatar (Turko-Mongol) raiders and invaders and with their religious Orthodox Christianity dogmas cemented since the 10th century. Rublev was a religious iconography painter with undoubted artistic skills, yet he serves to also represent the power of institutional organized religion over the unconvinced and terrorized population as we see eloquently when a non-believing woman is chased by menacing men near a river. Atheism came into vogue in Russia during the Soviet era when this movie was made and released in 1966 so we can wonder what the reactions of the audience to a lot of the religious focus of the film were.Beyond religion, Tarkovsky touches human themes of purpose and passion. He questions the human condition with loyalties and the vagaries of war, rape, plunder, and pillage. What does it that to raise a kid? A village? What does it take to murder nearly everyone in a village?Maybe not so much. I am also thinking of Elim Klimov's soviet WWII masterpiece Come and See (1985) where villagers in the "Enlightened" Modern Ages suffer a similar fate in different times and context. Are we doomed to repeat this savagery today in different ways? Will 2022 be different than 1422?Technically Tarkovsky manages exquisite visual scenes with trusted DOP, Vadim Yusov from Ivan's Childhood. This time he manages even more poignant composition, wide lens, motion and a mix of beautiful slow contemplative shots and actions sequences including invasion, fire, fighting, and horse falling, among highlights. The images are seriously superb and carry the story with immersive sensibility.The images are stunning and stay with me, the questions too. A haunting reminder of humanity's penchant for masked or overt savagery with self-appointed superiority and rationalization of control of ideas, people and property.

After his debut "Ivan's childhood" (1962), "Andrei Rublev" (1966) is the first "real" Tarkovsky. This means among other things that the mood of the film is philisophical and somewhat pessimistic. Because in the meantime the relatively liberal Chroesjtsjov years where over and the Brezjnev years were begun, it took a couple of years before the film was released abroad (and a couple of more years before the film could be seen in the Soviet Union itself).Just like with "Ivan the terrible" (1944 and 1958, Sergeij Eisenstein) situating the story in the Middle ages ultimately did not help to confuse the censors. They understood that the implied message was applicable to the present as well.The story is about an artist (icon painter) with a "writers block". In this respect it is comparable with "Otto e mezzo" (1963, Federico Fellini) and "Persona" (1966, Ingmar Bergman). In "Otto e mezzo" it is a film director who is suffering from a writers block and in "Persona" it is an actress.The artist in "Persona" is fictional, the artist in "Otto e mezzo" is autobiographical and the artist in "Andrei Rublev" is an historical person. However not much is known about the historical person of Andrei Rublev, so autobiographical elements could penetrate into the movie. It is telling that the Russian title of the film is "The passion of Andrei". Does "Andrei" maybe stands partially also for Andrei Tarkovsky?The similarity with "Persona" is striking in this respect that the origin for the writers block in both films lies in the cruelty of the world. Remarkable enough, despite the low spirited mood of most of the fim, Tarkovsky ends the film with a scene that comes close to an happy ending.

Movie starts with group of people laughing at a funny guy while hiding from the rain. Everyone was having a good time until three Christian monks enter their hut and ask a permission to wait out the rain. It felt like they were not welcome, that people were forced to let them in. After some time, men of Knyaz come and arrest the funny guy. This scene is the first example of Knyaz being brutal to his people and this movie has lots of examples like this. It does not shy away from the harshness of its time and shows it as it is.Then we switch to 1405. Where someone named Feofan The Greek is talking with one of the subordinates of Andrey Rublyov - Kirill. Feofan tries to persuade Kirill to come to Moscow and help him paint icons. What I have got from this scene is that Feofan does not actually need Kirill. It seemed like he was trying to get Andrey through Kirill.The next scene is proof of that. Kirill is sitting in his room and looks upset. Perhaps he understood that he is being used. In rage he badmouths other monks, compares the monastery to a bazaar and reminds them of the story from Bible where Jesus is doing the similar thing. Both the funny guy that was arrested and Kirill are important in this movie. They are going to come back in the future, and we would be able to see how they changed. This is always welcome in movies. It shows director's attention to details and that he is not using characters as fillers, but treating them as living, breathing human beings.1406. Andrey has arrived in Moscow and met Feofan. They are discussing the state of humans. Are they sinful or are they pious? We see how Andrey believes in human potential. He is very optimistic. This is very important as we would be able to observe his shift in this matter throughout the movie.1408. Here we are shown rituals of polytheists running naked and making love. Andrey is caught by them and rescued by a girl among them. They discuss their beliefs and it looks like they part at a definition of love. Andrey tells her that love should not be crazy and uncontrollable, that it should be responsible and conscious. Then the next day those polytheists are caught by men of Knyaz. When given a chance Andrey did not help her escape those men. What should we think? Should we think that Andrey is not brave enough to go against men of Knyaz? Should we think that he could have saved her but did not because of her beliefs?Then Andrey starts painting. But not really. His disciples readied everything, but Andrey is not starting. Andrey's helpers leave the Knyaz and are heading to work under his brother. It seems that Knyaz is jealous of his brother's riches. He commands to blind disciples of Andrey, so they won't be able to go further. Knyaz's brother teams up with Tatars and destroys Moscow. Along with the Chruch Andrey was painting. Andrey kills one of the attackers to save the mute girl who was helping him paint all these years. He is shocked as this was his first major sin he committed.Andrey has lost all the hope for people. He takes an oath to never speak again. 1412. Mute girl is tired of her life and marries one of Tatars. Andrey is getting more upset. His friends are dead, Russian brothers are killing each other, Russian sisters are marrying Tatars.1423. Men of Knyaz are searching for someone who could forge a large bell for a Church. Kid Boris uses this opportunity to climb the ranks and become closer to Knyaz. He tells those men that he knows a secret that his father has left before his death. Boris is overseeing the construction of the Church and seems nervous and lost. When he found that clay, he looked very relieved. Andrey is watching him and is suspicious?Kirill tries to persuade Andrey to go work under Troitsa, but Andrey does not speak. Knyaz with foreigners come to celebrate the opening of the Church. Boris is hallucinating as only he knows that he does not know how to forge a bell. Movie reaches its climax when bell ring is heard. We find Boris lying near a tree and crying as he understands that he was nearly executed. Andrey comes to cheer him up and speaks for the first time in years. He takes Boris under his wing and is planning to go work in Troitsa.Overall, this movie was very calm paced and relaxing. It was refreshing to see characters take their time in their speech and pause when they wanted to pause. Also, the Edige's lack of understanding of Mary's virginity seemed very interesting to me. I do not have any thoughts on that, just wanted to point out that I like director's decision to have this scene in the movie. As for that funny guy, he was released from prison and wanted to kill Andrey for "selling him out". In the end, guy forgives Andrey and continues being himself. Movie ends by presenting Andrey's well-known arts.

What intimidates on first glance: a 3-hour plus Russian movie, told in chapter form (like a proper 1200 page Russian novel), about a famous Russian painter, and realized on screen in a deeply sustained, poetic film style, is hardly the best offering to a man or a woman (or a subliterate teenage boy) expecting the latest in nutritional entertainment from t.v or the local cineplex. But no, this flick is gripping, stark, visually mesmerizing from start to finish due to director Tarkovsky's ingenious eye, and full of unsettling, intense scenes of intellectual as well as spiritual action, man. Got it! And, yes, there's plenty of atrocities, as well. You can't film over 5,000 extras and not expect some excitement, especially when the subject covered is the wasteland that was 15th century Russia. And the damn thing even has rampaging Tartars in it, with only a sadly absent soundtrack of decent metal making the experience a real head-trip. Not convinced? It was banned in Russia. Lots of powerful contemplation on hand here, as the subject is really creativity; what motivates it, what sustains it, and, most importantly, how can man justify being creative and producing art in an evil, uncomprehending world? Of course other equally light, philosophical issues are explored as well, like religion and war, etc. Film's final chapter, depicting the trial of a teenage bell-maker and his comeuppance at the hands of an evil Zsar, is by far one of the most poetic episodes I've ever seen on film. Well worth the time. Additionally, the only film I've seen to document 15th century Russia and include the popular Rudy Ray Moore epithet: "motherf---er!". Powerful.

Some beautiful, some terrible, some peaceful, some violent. The great Russian icon painter Andrei Rublev lives among the great turmoil in Russia's 15th century with princes' fights and rivalries, Tatar invasions and heathens' ceremonies. There are also religious discussions and faith affirmations among the characters suitable to an epoch of intense spiritual religious life like it were Middle Ages. There are extraordinary sequences like for instance the sack of Vladimir and the casting of the huge bell for the prince. Andrei Rublev goes through all this somehow anguished and without feeling to decide to go painting the icons on the Trinity Monastery like he had been asked to. At last and after the bell was built and put to work he finally decides to go to the Monastery and paint those admirable icons we can see at the end of the movie.

reviews.review_title: A compelling and moving work of art
reviews.content: Consider Steven Speilberg a lucky man- he is one of the few "great visionary" directors who has had a large body of work to his name. Most others, such as Kubrick, only did a handful of films, although each is well remembered. Tarkovsky is one of those who was unfortunate to die early- in his late fifties, I think- and leave behind an impressive resume. This is the best of his seven (circulated) films, and has to be watched more than once to be fully appreciated. The performances, most of which are by highly talented actors who would never be seen in anything else, will be remembered as long as films are shown, and the photography is some of the best black-and-white work that has been done. This could be the best epic of the sixties. Make sure you're concentrating when you watch it- its perfect for a rainy day. Co-scripted by Andrei Konochlavsky, who would later go on to direct "Runaway Train."

As admirable as an act of courage as a work of art. How can an artist keep creating while repression and cruelty surround him? Answer: to bring some joy into people's lives. The Soviet government kept this one in the can five years. So direct, no possible editing could have changed its meaning. The whole cast and crew should get medals.
Play Andrey Rublev! It is fast and easy to view! A good way to spend your time. Be the best!

Andrei Rublev -1966A picturization of the historical period and its situations where it's not all about Andrei Rublev - a medieval Russian painter, but it shows the various lives through different characters which Andrei Rublev observes.The early 15th-century Russian period takes us to a slow journey where it shows the different thinkings and way of living of people which offers very crucial messages through very strong dialogues like " today they will praise, tomorrow they will abuse what they praised yesterday, and after that, they will forget both you and me " and " you need to forgive yourself before God forgives you". The story has a confusing point of view and will be a different journey for different viewers. There are strong topics like faith in God, what is a sin? doing sin is right or wrong in different societies and thinkings? ". This is a movie that a viewer may see with a confused point of view and may get bored because of its slow pace.There are so many possibilities in this movie and its difficult to describe this one-sidedly.Although its a black and white feature, excluding that actual artwork by Andrei Rublev at the end of the movie. Even in black and white, we will see some beautiful landscapes and a glance of old Russian architecture which still can be experienced in there culture and living. The camera is very beautifully used showing some slow and fast pan shots and some truck shots, especially if we mention fire scenes and horse-riding scenes.Keep your mind open and welcome this art-history to make an impact on your heart and mind.

You must be patient to appreciate the greatness in this film. It's long, but portions of it are as majestic as any film even made, there is some astonishing camera work, and, yes, some of it is trademark Tarkovsky, ponderous and with seemingly superfluous imagery and dialogue.I like "Solaris" more (in fact is one of my favorites), if only because the bafflement of the characters in "Solaris" at the alien presence is more perfectly matched in that film to Tarkovsky's often baffling style. But if "Roublev" is your favorite movie, I'm not going to argue with you. Roublev's, his brethren filmmakers', and, occasionally our own, struggle to create great things speaks powerfully from this film.

Solonitsin is my ideal of man for all times. His perfect acting is so deep and touching. The Love scene with Tatar people and his girl - is the most powerful love scene in the whole cinematography even there is no any sex or naked people. Emotions are given in so intelligent way! In new cinema this is rare case. And also such scenes are relevant for contemporary Russia more than ever - Russian girls prefer to migrate to EU or US in order to receive fancy clothes. Final episodes with young guy trying to build in chaotic Russian realities are also very impressive. That is the best example of successful project management. Thank you, Andrey Tarkovsky! I love your Russia.

Andrei Rublev is a solid work which is not just an autobiography of the great monk and icon painter, but also a picture of the life, troubles and believes of a Russian folk in a 15th century. Andrei Tarkovsky, author of the picture, structures the movie into eight novellas trying to open the life of the rabbles though the Rublev's formation. We can see how the nature of protagonist develops from the blind believer to the naïve monk and finally, experiencing the "live and death", he reaches understanding and admission of himself and of what he can and must do for the humanity. By this movie review I want to reflect my perception of how the crisis of believe in a combination with the existential crisis of the folk helped Andrei Rublev find his own way in expressing his talent.
To start with let me divide the movie into tree parts: way to the church, raid of the Tatars and building of the bell. From the first stories the picture is fulfilled with the poverty, dirt and humility of the Russian lower-class people. We see how they are living, resting, and even making a pagan religious rite. The life of a common peasant is not that one which a proper religious Christian man should live like. This is what Andei Rublev see when he first starts his way to the painting of the monarch's church. Being motivated in the beginning, going out from the monastery where he was living, he faces harsh reality and this reality makes him understand that people do need help. Looking at all this sins, he does not tern aside, vice versa, he tries to understand why these happening. This is well illustrated in the part "Andrei's passions" when he starts the dialog with Theophanies the Greek; here Andrei tries to prove the folk's religious ignorance: "And new troubles are pouring on the peasant: then the Tatars three times in the fall, then hunger, then pestilence, but he still works, he works ... He carries his cross humbly, does not despair, but is silent and suffers, only God prays so that he has enough strength. May not the Almighty forgive them for such darkness?" If Theophanies states that people were and will stay ignorant and evil, considering the events of the Jesus "Last Supper" and stating that today the storyline would be the same, Andrei prefer to emphasize the repentance, for him: "If only one evil is remembered, then before God you will never be happy". The main source of the battles between them is that Theophanies wants Andrei just to use his talent and create because this gift was given to him by God, when Andrei himself want to create only in order to help people and promote right religion.
Rublev's ideology creates first troubles when they start the work on the church. Looking at the lost and cruel nation, he does not want to create "Last Judgment", considering that people need something light and easy in order to become inspired, but not something that will frighten them even more. Finally, he follows his path, and creates a beautiful and light peace. Nevertheless, that become unimportant when the brother of the monarch and the Tatars occupy the city. This is when Andrei losing his passion and in another bottle with Theophanies (his ghost), they are changing places. "It snows, nothing is worse when it snows in the temple" - with these words we see that Theophanies again lose the bottle. Allegory with snow, for me, is the cool off of Rublev's passion; temple which Andrei tried to fulfill with light, now is snowing. This could be the reason why Andrei is killing one of the brigands in order to protect a woman who will further betray him. That become a reason why Andrei stops painting and takes a vow of silence.
The last part is fully dedicated to the boy Boriska, whose story brings Andrei back to life. A boy, who lost his family, clings his chance for better life and risking everything builds a bell. Boldly, stubbornly, passionately Boriska takes a lead, bluffing with the special secret which he never knew. Nevertheless, the fortune and God's gift let Boriska indeed create a masterpiece. When it works, a boy just becomes devastated, yet his deed fulfills Rublev and he breaks his vow with compassionate words to Boriska: "You see how it turned out well, stop it you ... Here we go with you together. You pour bells, I write icons ...such a holiday for people ... ". Here we should again underline "for people", because now we can see that his faith is back.
To sum up, the movie rightfully called a masterpiece, which managed to not only to tell the biography of a great icon painter, but to call for the thoughts of how the religion should be approached and presented and to explain how Christianity can reflect on the common people's sins. Andrei Rublev is a picture of religious player who felt peoples' troubles, lived his own, managed to overcome them, and revive it in his works.

Films like "Andrei Rubylov" (1969) make you realise why film-making is the most vital art of the 20th. century. A highly demanding and often gruelling film, which does not flinch from the horrors or the intense beauty of Mediaeval Russia. The scenes evolve slowly, in real time, each building on the other to reveal an almost alien world - as strange as the worlds of "Solaris" or "Stalker". Like the great Russian writers such as Gogol, Tolstoy or Dostoievsky; Tarkovsky examines the role of religious faith and belief in a cruel and irrational world. It must be seen (if possible), on the wide screen, in order to appreciate the brilliant black and white cinematography. "Andei Rubylov" is in my top 10 favourite films.

Although Tarkovsky's "Andrei Rublev" is considered to be a masterpiece of Soviet cinema (as well as all Tarkovsky's works), in the 1960s the movie created a wave of criticism and was opposed by the Soviet state. The reasons for those censorships and rejections lie on many factors, including misrepresentation (according to State authorities) of Russian people and their history. However, the more interesting possible reason is the figure of Andrei Rublev himself and his role in the Eastern Church. The importance of icons, as well as their painters' for Orthodox Christianity, is immense. As noted in the lecture, there were periods of iconoclasm or rejection and destruction of icons, and "the fact that they live through this period of iconoclasm made icons all the more important. And so icons are very characteristic of Eastern Church today" (Lecture on "Eastern Orthodoxy). Indeed, icons are still an essential part of the Eastern Church and, thus, the painters of icons are valued highly in Russia. Rublev's style as an iconographer, moreover, was made a model for later church paintings while he was even canonized as a saint by the Russian Orthodox Church. Thus, the importance of Rublev to the Russian religion and national identity cannot be exaggerated. Tarkovsky, however, created a piece of art reconsidering Rublev's life with artistic freedom and risks. In his "Andrei Rublev", the audience can see Christianity in the 15th century from a new angle, as a combination of violent and yet "faith-giving" spiritual religion.
First, the obvious pattern presented in the movie is common people's judgmental attitude towards the Church, or, in other words, the general (but moderate) criticism of the Church as an institution. The time that Tarkovsky depicts is deeply religious, and the ones who oppose Christianity or do not belong to traditional Christian beliefs are being chased and jailed. It is similar to early campaigns launched against pagans tribes such as of Teutonic Knights' though on a lesser scale (Lecture on "Eastern Orthodoxy"). The first episode where the audience encounters this type of campaign (now in the 15th century) is in Part 1, Jester. A jester or "skomorokh" mocks and criticizes the rulers and church through his art, dancing, and singing. Later, he is beaten and prisoned by soldiers for his mockery. Next, Rublev meets the pagans who, in their shameless nudity, are celebrating Kupala night. One of the girls who, Andrei meets responses to his prejudice that her people are being chased and tortured because of different religious views. Interestingly, it is as if Andrei's every journey is accompanied by the violence of the Church.
The later analysis needs separation of artist from his art since it is difficult to assume Tarkovsky's religious beliefs only from his works. Therefore, as it is not certain whether Tarkovsky put his views into Rublev, I will refer to whoever possesses the depicted views as Andrei (either Tarkovsky or Rublev). Andrei's religious perception diverges from Christian tradition since, in a way, he humanizes Jesus. Andrei sees Jesus, not as a God but as a more human, a more "person", and the scene of Jesus's crucifixion shows this point quite clearly. He likens Jesus to Russian peasant by combining a Jesus bearing a cross with Rublev's monologue on Russian men: "They keep working and working, bearing his cross with humility" (44:02). This contradicts dogmatic Christian tradition where a God is nothing like humanity but divine. For example, Patriarch Timothy says, "I drew a comparison concerning Him who in reality has no comparison with the created beings at all" (Apology of Patriarch Timothy of Baghdad). In other words, God cannot be compared or likened to mere human beings as he is divine and above others.
Yet, this does not necessarily mean that Tarkovsky opposed religion. Rather, he shows a paradoxical combination of Church brutality and human beliefs and faith. The latter is done through Andrei Rublev's discussion with Theophanes the Greek when the audience witnesses the clash of religious views between followers of the same religion. The main disagreement between them comes from their perception of God and humanity. Theophanes is quite cynical in his views as he sees humans as being consumed by sins and evil. Thus, he believes, in the Day of Judgment, they are all going to burn. He claims that if God came back to Earth, people would crucify him again. God, says Theophanes, should not be merciful but vindictive since all evil and betrayal come from humans. Therefore, he sees people as low and dirty, while God is the one who should punish them.
In contrast to Theophanes, Andrei Rublev represents the typical Christian view of God and humanity. He has trust and belief in humans and sees in them only good. When Theophanes asks Andrei whether humans are "dark", Andrei agrees and yet, he notes, "But whose fault is it?" He advocates for the better in human nature and admires how people endure the harshness of life and still can do good deeds and feel love. His sincere beliefs in human acted as an inspiration for viewers of that time and strengthened to some extent spirituality.
In conclusion, though Tarkovsky's work is not an biography or documentary, he managed to create a critical and yet inspiring film. Through his characters he analyses the religion and its place in people's lives. Tarkovsky, then, created a piece of art that depicts art as a religious experience and journey.

When the world was immeasurable, when your place was fixed, when a mile was distance, in the rain and mud and when life meant even less than it usually does. When cruelty and lack of any purpose were not just the asset of the most evil of men or, respectively, the discussion of philosophers, but the very routine of each and every day. When knowledge was not much, when there were few ways to go and there was no middle way, no finesse, no considering the options. When disaster was disaster and a calling was a calling. In this setting, also heavily impregnated with religion, art and artist struggle to come of age and fulfill themselves. This is no redefinition of a style, it is not a matter of taste, it's to be or not to be. Can art exist in such a world? Can the artist find a reason to go on and can he find the conditions in which his inner talent will spark and he'll start creating? Nobody seems to need it; nobody seems to want it, not the poor and not the rich or the powerful. Andrei Rublev first and then the young Boris struggle to find reason to all the madness. They don't find, but they create it. One single, but spectacular advantage can be attributed to art in such a context: it is essential; it is the way to set apart man from beast and that it does. Not so convincing for Andrei but very for Boris. But, of course, Andrei fails and Boris doesn't. Boris is the prototype of the artist: desperate, he will go for the prize and gamble all on it, and he will be walking in the dark making gut decision after gut decision all to way to the end. And he will get there, and of course be overwhelmed and feeling really like coming out of a trance. The moment when he cries by the pole and Andrei comes to comfort him, that moment, what he lives there is the single greatest weakness of man and the single greatest feeling on this planet, 5 minutes for which I'd give the rest of my life. But, of course, it is a weakness. This kind of art, this kind of humanization by art, this is not a real thing in the 21st century. None will buy this now. When turning from animal to man, that might have done the trick. We now know in our century that science is really the mother of them all. And art, grand as it might be, it's much more complicated. Even though, each true artist, even today, would give an arm and a leg to be in the place of Boris building his bell. It is not that Boris it's talented at something, he's just a skilled blue collar worker as far as talent is concerned. It's his beauty; his youth; how he believes and how he goes for all or nothing and how out of his vision the final, significant, triumphant, inspiring product comes. It is pure creation. It is not a coincidence that the best scene in the entire movie is him mastering and harnessing his own creational inferno, him almost delirious with concentration and emotion in the middle of the flowing rivers of melted bronze falling to fill the clay mold. The movie is well done but the first part is kind of fragmented and slow paced. Many of the supporting actors do a very poor job of their parts and though not void of merit or even majestic scenes, I'd say that the first 2 hours or so fall into the category of flawed genius. It all picks up and starts to really be spectacular with Boris's story. Of course, this part benefits greatly from the background and the mood set by the first one. More could be said about this great film. Will it convince with its message? No, our world has nothing to do with that. Will it inspire? Yeah, it will make you throw away your TV set and start writing that novel or something. It is not a perfect movie, because of the lesser first part. It is, never the less, a genuine masterpiece.

This movie is a narrative of XV century Russian monk Andrei Rublev's life. XV century Rus' is torn by internal feuds of knyazs, constant raids of Tatars and famine. Nevertheless, life goes on, and despite of this tough period icon painter Rublev is able to live his life and make art. Andrei Rublev, who is full of faith and love for people, leaves the monastery. He has all the knowledge that he received during his monastery teaching. Andrei is faced with harshness and roughness of world outside monastery, with reality, horror, pain, betrayal and all the sins that fill the world. His worldview and his faith are regularly tested throughout the whole movie.
The film's idea is centered around the dispute between Andrei Rublev and Theophanes the Greek. Theophanes, though is not a monk, is a wise and kind person. Nevertheless, he is cynical towards people and art, which is reflected in his claim:"I serve the Lord, not the people. And what about praise? Today they praise you, tomorrow they will criticize you for the same reason they praised you yesterday. Then the day after tomorrow they'll forget about you. They will forget about you, and they will forget about me. Everything is vanity and dust! Even those things greater than these had been forgotten. The human race has already committed all stupidity and meanness possible, and now it only repeats them. Whatever goes around comes around! It all keeps spinning and spinning! If Jesus came back to Earth, he would be crucified again!"In making this comment Theophanes means that as time passes by, people are prone to change their vision and opinion on what is right and appropriate, and those whom they glorify today are condemned and forgotten by them tomorrow. He is highly skeptical about humanity claiming that people are ungrateful beings that do not learn from their mistakes and keep repeating them.
Andrei, on the other hand, is full of love and faith in God and people. He tries to justify all the atrocities that people commit:"People need to be reminded that they are human beings more often. That they are Russians. One blood and one Earth. There is evil everywhere. There always will be hunters, eager to sell you for thirty pieces of silver. And more troubles keep pouring on the peasant: Tatars' raids three times in the fall, then hunger, then pestilence. But peasant keeps working and working. Keeps carrying his cross humbly. He does not despair, he is silent and patient. He only prays to God for strength. How can the Almighty not forgive such peasant for his ignorance?"In other words, Andrei is optimistic of humanity and believes that it is possible to appeal to people's conscience by reminding them of their nature. In his view, despite of all the sins and evils of this world people keep working and keep hoping for the best and therefore deserve forgiveness from the Almighty God. But later, after Andrei goes through a difficult life path, their roles change. Andrei is disappointed and wants to painting icons, Theophanes from the height of his knowledge, is trying to change his mind:"-You know what, I will never paint icons again.
Why?No one needs this. That's it.So they burned the iconostasis, big deal. Do you know how many times they burned mine? In Pskov, in Novgorod, in Galich! You are taking a great sin upon yourself!"The essence of this dialogue is that Theophanes thinks that being as gifted painter as Andrei is and not using it for good is a sin. Later Andrei understands that the more evils there is in the world the more kindness and beauty there should be. Therefore, he should be ready to devote his life and talent to art.
Through the final episode with the bell, film director Tarkovsky demonstrates the victory of Andrei Rublev in a dispute with Theophanes. The episode reveals everything that Rublev could not express in words in his dispute about the human nature. Kindness and love that Andrei was looking for, he found in himself, realized his ability to create and spread it, even after his death, because art is permanent.
Director Tarkovsky definitely coped with the task of narrating episodes of Rublev's life. Not only he successfully conveyed famous icon painter's feelings and emotions through his movie, but he also was able to immerse viewers in that atmosphere of crisis in XV century Rus'. The lesson I got from this film is to never give up your hopes, believe in yourself and keep doing your best, because despite of all roughness and hardship of our lives we are able to create and spread love, kindness and happiness which help us during our lifetimes. This film despite of all violent and cruel scenes conveys a very kind message, 10/10.

reviews.review_title: a genuine epic of Tarkovsky's faith for art
reviews.content: Russians must be really proud to own one of the greatest director, Andrei Tarkovsky and Alexander Sokurov, his unique successor. Well, I'm proud for them.Knowing nothing about this film but its director, I bought this DVD and set out watching it. Its vigour and beauty really overwhelmed me to the core. Even in black and white, Tarkovsky's cinematic language is surprisingly daring and comprehensive. Getting used to the tranquility in his later works, now I'm convinced he's capable of dealing with other uproarious themes like violence and comedy.As Tarkovsky showed me this grandiose historic event, I unconsciously related it to Sokurov's "Russian Ark". I found that living in a country of great amplitude really endows people with special talents. Russia becomes a magic country since the first time the two directors captured my heart.This film contains many subtle, symbolic elements both in dialogues and camera, keeping you observing and thinking. It's a panorama of the medieval Russia in a episodic style. Each story directly or indirectly affects the life of Rublyov. With all the characters not associated in a classical way, its cinematic style is itself a memorable attempt to portray a helpless individual in a historical fate.I wonder whether it is just a coincidence that the great painter in the film and the great director out of the film share the name Andrei. Maybe like what Tarkovsky said in an interview, all the artists share the same fate to go through the unpleasant darkness of the world to create genuine artworks.He told us to learn to enjoy loneliness. I did for long. He loves horses. I'd occasionally stop my footstep, trying to hear a horse running by.I'm not superstitiously worshiping him. I'm just trying to dig some of his feelings --- the inspirations that have enlightened a great director.

Probably visually the best movie Tarkovsky ever made, but sadly the story doesn't really have theme, there are little developed themes through the episodes, but they feel too short, after the pagans we don't see more religious persecution, something I really feel ashamed they left behind, the expiation is only showed in the last chapter, and the talent is only barely mention with that greek man and when Ciril scolds Andrei.Also the begining and the end are bad, the begining is meaningless, "daring", what? Andrei never dares to do anything other than killing a tatar to protect that girl, that may be enough for some but the fact that he never struggles to make his icons and actually we never see him painting icons, makes me seriously question if the movie is about painting, the only daring I bealive is worthy was that young boy with the bell, interentings yeah, but the begining still feeling meaningless, especially with that horse rolling, I mean, why? It's super random, something bad for a serious movie, and the ending, almost 9 minutes straight of just paintings?, that not ok because I'm watching a movie, its ending must be meaningful and important to the plot, how would you feels if you go to see an opera and they only show you sculptures for 9 minutes straight as the ending?,Despite the movie having not really a plot, it's an episode movie and I can forgive it for that, but the episodes don't really share a theme and that a shame because the faith, art and hope are never developed, we never learn something about the importance of faith, about the role of art, about the hope of the people for a better world, nothing, and that's trutly a shame.As I remember, when a random scene without purpose is thrown, is called "filler", but aparently, if Tarkovsky does it is "art", examples of these: the begining, the juglar scene, Ciril acusing monks of being commerciants (we never saw clues of this), the snake in the mud, Andrei playing with a girl we never met before, the boy reading the bible, that other girl crying to some paint in the wall, thay guy searching for clay (maybe a hint that he doesn't actually know the secret for making bells, but too long, could've been done shorter), the ending with the paintings.The quotes of the crucifixion and the 1Corinthians 13 are interesting, but they just pop out of nowhere, especially the second one, feel unnatural and seems that Tarkovsky wanted the scenes just to appear "deep", "meaningful" and "artistic" so he just throwed some random wisdom there, something we will witness again in his later movies.Despite that, I enjoyed the movie, specially the second part, when the random filling is less abundant, overall a bit pretentious and full of missed oportunities but still good.

reviews.review_title: Film of the art of icons and bells.
reviews.content: Excellent photography, the contrasts of black and white create a photographic image in each frame. A slow and long film that pleases and interests the art of icons and bells.

Caution! This film is well worth watching BUT only for those who are willing to take the time and effort (nearly 3 1/2 hrs - at least) to watch and think about the meaning of the various stories that make up this epic work of art.Perhaps the film can be viewed and enjoyed in a single sitting, but I doubt it. The closest analogy I can offer is that watching the film is like viewing fine paintings in an art gallery or savoring the taste and aroma of vintage wines.(SPOILER) Visually the scenes are striking with many panoramic views. The use of black and white (until the very last few minutes of the film) creates a hypnotic, dream-like effect that heightens the mood of the scenes. Some scenes show cruel treatment of animals and barbaric treatment of human beings.

reviews.review_title: Visually stunning, can't say about the rest
reviews.content: This film has possibly the best opening scene in the history of cinema. All the rest is classic beautiful Tarkovksy too.That said, I didn't finish the film - towards the end of the first half I found my mind wandering so that it seemed pointless to go on. I was left with the impression that this might be a lot more interesting to anyone who either is religious or knows anything at all about Christianity. As is, my ignorant atheist self was just left to admire the pictures as the content flew over my head.Might try to rewatch sometime.

This film makes an interesting bookend with Antonioni's L'Avventura. I watched both films recently and they both absorb you into the world each movie is reproducing. Deep in visual metaphor and amazing to look at. The only problem I have with both films is they are both so deep in meaning (both hidden and apparent) that they require multiple viewings, which I'm having a hard time finding the time for. 9/10

reviews.review_title: So boring i had to stand up and leave
reviews.content: Yes it was beautiful, but it's just arrogant to make it that long. I'm sorry but I had to stand up and leave after more than two hours (knowing there was still one hour more to go). For me this was the best part of my experience, going out of the cinema alone, in a cool summer evening directly to St. James's Park in London, liberating myself from the monotony and dullness of the film and becoming impregnated with the fragrance and colour in the park. I could only bear it until just after the invasion, I've read that there was colour afterwards and maybe my experience would have changed, but i believe that whilst you cannot intend to summarise any piece of Beethoven's work in a two minute radio version, this film could have been shorter because the viewer deserves respect and his time is valuable.

A truly unique movie, the closest you'll get to seeing Breughel or Hieronymus Bosch in cinema. Tarkovsky shows us the life and times of Russian painter Andrei Rublev (±1365-1430) in a way that only Tarkovsky can, his trademark meandering camera hypnotizing the viewer, enabling an almost meditative state that allows us to gain deep insights into art, religion and the human condition. Parts 4, 6 and 8 in particular are fantastic, revealing the chaos and trials of medieval Europe in haunting fashion. The payoff comes in the form of the gorgeous, timeless finale - so well executed.Still, this is not as perfect a work as Stalker or Solaris. I found parts 5 and 7 to be outright boring, perhaps because some orthodox religious themes were lost on me. But these are minor quibbles - take your time to absorb this movie, even if you don't consider yourself the type to enjoy 3 hour allegories about obscure Russian icon painters. For better or for worse, it will be a once in a lifetime experience.

reviews.review_title: Must be seen in a theater.....sigh
reviews.content: Watching it on video gives only a shadow of the power of this film. The themes of plague, art, meaning of life. purpose in work: all valuable to everyone. The DVDs and Blu-Rays are good for learned commentary and that is about it. True, you can see the editing in a video, but the size of a theater screen in combination with the beautifully thematic photography are essential to this film. Brilliant in a theater! (Shown in 2018, e.g., at the Cleveland Cinemateque). Very, very good on home theater system.

reviews.review_title: The sublime is a sense of the infinite in nature
reviews.content: This movie tore me up. I love all of Tarkovsky's stuff, but this one stands out to me because of its complexity and, well, richness, even compared to his other works.  It's a very long, tense film, and the meditation that it facilitates in turn makes for a certain kind of marvellous enlightenment at the end.

reviews.review_title: Slow Cinema or Cinema for the Slow?
reviews.content:
I never expected action scenes in a Tarkovsky movie! This is probably the most dynamic and diverse movie from his entire filmography!
Deep, epic, emotional, meditative atmosphere, shocking scenes, philosophical themes, subtle dialogue scenes, stunning visuals; I'm telling you... this is the opposite of boring!

I hadn't studied this film in depth so much and would suggest a review reading if you want further information. Well worth a watch! It is lengthy but excellent especially if you are looking for a realistic portrayal of medieval Russian history.

Andrey Rublyov is a Soviet biographical movie directed in 1966 by Andrei Tarkovsky- one of the prominent and most influential directors in the history of cinema. This movie is about the 15th-century Russian icon painter- Andrey Rublyov, the role of whom was played by Anatoly Solonitsyn. It consists of 8 parts, each describing a certain period of his life. From my perspective, by shooting this film Andrey Tarkovsky wanted to introduce us to the extraordinary person, a medieval painter Andrey Rublyov, since his personality is being unknown for many people due to lack of information about him. And Tarkovsky chooses to introduce exactly Andrey Rublyov to show the connection of art and religion because in Andrey Rublyov's life both religion and art helped him to survive despite political and social difficulties of his time. This movie review will focus on Andrey Rublyov's personality and show the way religion and art helped him to survive.
Firstly, the mission of the director was to introduce an extraordinary artist, who is unfortunately not so known among people. From the plot of the movie, the viewer learns some facts about Andrey Rublyov. From the episode "Jester" we get to know that Andrey was a monk and the part of a Trinity. From the episode "Theophanes the Greek" it seems clear for us that Andrey was a pupil of Theophanes the Greek- Byzantine Greek artist and one of the most popular icon painters of Muscovite Russia. From further episodes, we see that Andrey had decorated several churches of the country such as the Cathedral church in Vladimir. The episode "Silence" shows that at one point in his life Andrey took a vow of silence.
Secondly, the idea of the director was to show the importance of religion and art in people's life. This is shown by one of the key moments of Andrey's life. This all starts with the episode "The Passion" when Andrei and Theophanes argued about religion in the forest. Theophanes claimed that people are stupid and evil. He proves it by saying that if Jesus would be alive people would anyway crucify him. Andrey, however, disagrees and says that people crucified Christ to obey God. This Andrey's point is supported by a reenactment of Christ's crucifixion, where on the snow-covered hillside Christ is crucified, however, people nearby were acting against their will just to obey God, because they loved him. However, the whole movie is set in the 15th century and further episodes of the film perfectly illustrate the whole cruelty of that century such as Tatar invasion, sibling betrayal. Andrey sees the cruelty and deception of people and disappoints in them. By seeing how Russian people cut themselves, their evilness, he recognizes the truth of his Greek teacher's point and he loses his belief and takes the vow of silence. Only by meeting Boriska- a boy who had no skills, however, agrees to cast the bell returns Rublev's faith in people, faith in God. He breaks his vow of silence and suggests the boy carry on their work together.
The scene with the bell symbolizes Andrey's finding of God. This scene is emphasized by the director's device. The whole film was shot in black and white and the scene when the bell rings is shown in colors, symbolizing Andrey's belief's reborn.
This movie differs from other religious movies in a sense that it is not strictly religious, because many church rules are darkened there, such as skirmishes of church brothers. This movie is about the essence of Christian teaching: repentance, forgiveness, and humanity.
Despite how hard the times were, art such as a religion gave people belief in a better life and improved their lives. Art and religion gave people hope and strength. Tarkovsky chose to direct Andrey Rublyov's life because he was a prominent icon painter and a faithful believer, thus he was able to survive and gave people hope and strength through his works in these hard times of the 15th century.
To sum up, a film of Andrey Tarkovsky in 1966 narrates the life of Andrey Rublev- a famous icon painter of the 15th century. Even though Andrei Rublyov was an artist lived in the 15th century his personality was very close and appealing for people of the 70th. That is because Andrey Rublyov was a person who showed that with the help of religion and art people come through different struggles, deal with any kind of problems and difficulties. Difficulties surrounded people at all times we just should always have strength and hope and should not forget about humanity and forgiveness that religion gives us. After the film was directed a lot of people started to be religious meaning that Tarkovsky reached his main aim- he showed people the essence of Christianity.

The movie "Andrey Rublyov" by Tarkovsky is based on the background of Russia during the early 15th century, times when Russian people experienced difficult situations. The film demonstrates the different stages of the life of well-known icon painter Andrey Rublyov, his talent, his relationship with other people and the outside world, and his faith. Besides this, three hours of the film shows different ideas such as reflections on sins, faith in God, a difficult period in people's lives due to the Mongol Tatar invasion, and the relationship of political and religious forces. The main character, Andrey, is being invited for decorations of several cathedrals and monasteries, such as Andronikov Monastery, Cathedral of the Annunciation, and Assumption Cathedral, however, at some point, he decides to quit painting. His talent is described as the gift of God, and he spends several years to understand the truth of his talent and to find himself. However, the main idea of the film is not centered on the life path of the talented iconographer, Tarkovsky used the character of the iconographer as a symbol to illustrate the changes like the increasing influence of Byzantine Christianity and Mongol -Tatar invasions, that were happening and affecting people' life at that time.The growing influence of Byzantine Christianity on the religious faith and beliefs of Russian people is depicted in the scenes of the life path of Andrey Rublyov, by showing his main work and talent. After the Great Schism in 1045, two different churches of Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches were separated. Byzantine Empire played an important role in the development of Eastern Church. One of the patriarchates of the Eastern Church was in Russian land, which emerged after the baptism of St.Vladimir in 988. After violent conversions, one of the main events happened was the arrival of educated churchman and painters from Byzantine. So, the arrival of these people should have affected architecture and art. These kinds of changes can be seen in the movie, which is presented by the character of Theophanes the Greek, who was the master like Andrey. However, from the conversation between him and Andrey, two different points of view and style can be seen. Theophanes was disappointed by people, thinking that they were sinners who make mistakes every time, and in his illustrations, God was not merciful. However, Andrey believed that it was acceptable to make sins if people repent about it. Moreover, he thought that people of Russia should not forget that they were "one faith, one land and one blood". His view highlights the concepts of Jesus's Teachings, such as compassion, peace, forgiveness.
Another example of the effect of Byzantine Christianity is the interaction between the Grand Prince and bishops or priests. In the movie, the religious cathedrals and monasteries were decorated or built by the order of the Grand Prince, and it can be seen that bishops and Grand Prince had political interactions. This is the same with the political and religious situation in Byzantine Empire since there also popes and priests had political influence. In the case with the bell construction, the Grand Prince was the one who ordered the bell and controlled its construction. These examples illustrate the concept that religion in Russia in the 15th century was under the influence of Eastern or Byzantine Christianity.During the period of Tatar-Mongol invasions, people in Russian land experienced a very harsh time. The character of the iconographer is used here as an example of one who experienced and witnessed all of the cruelties which had left its imprints on his talent and work. These invasions make him lose trust in people and be disappointed about them. The one whom he thought to be his people, allied with invaders, and destroyed everything. He had to kill the enemy in order to save the woman, which should not be considered as a wrong thing to do. However, he is strongly affected by this situation and started to have inner conflicts with himself which eventually led him to make a vow of silence and quit his job as a painter. At this point, his Tarkovsky tries to explain that there might be situations that even can influence the religious person with a strong belief. However, here the concept of forgiveness and pity in Jesus's teaching again highlighted. During their conversation, Theophanes mentioned the concept from Scripture: "Learn to do good, seek the truth, save the oppressed, protect an orphan, ... and if the sins are scarlet, I shall whiten them". This idea is the same as the one which Andrey believed, that people could do sins but they should eventually repent. However, he decided not to forgive himself. The Tatar-Mongol invasions affected many people, but in this movie a character with Andrey Rublyov is used as a symbol, as an example, how devastating effects had these situations in people's faith.The final moment is the time when the iconographer witnesses the success of a young boy on bell construction. Relying on God and asking for help from God, the boy could finish and make the good bell without any secret way of construction. After this, Andrey broke his vow of silence and with the boy they moved to start their art work again . Here, the movie is trying to explain that Rublyov realized the iconography, or the talent for the art was the gift of God and the best way to illustrate the will of God.
Overall, the movie "Andrey Rublyov" possesses both simple and complex ideas about the religious concepts, beliefs that were influenced by the circumstances happening at that period of time. Living under harsh situations, people in Russia had to face a lot of cruelties which might eventually cause disbelief or wrong perception of main religious concepts. The character of the iconographer is used to a key point to reveal all of these situations, doubts, and true belief.

reviews.review_title: The Bell - the light at the end of the tunnel.
reviews.content:
The Bell - the light at the end of the tunnel.Andrei Rublev, film directed by Andrei Tarkovsky in 1966, is a drama describing the life of 15-century Russia through the main character, an icon painter Andrei Rublev starred by Anatoly Solonitsyn. An eight-episode film depicts different stages of internal state of the main character and his attitudes towards his artworks within the medieval Russia experiencing political instabilities, Tatar raids, persecution of pagans, and famine. This black and white film with live background sounds could make the spectators to feel the nature, atmosphere of that Russian land. During the whole three-hour film, it is showing the hopelessness of the peoples' life at that time that are tortured by hardships. In addition to scenes of tortured people, the film is also full of dead or suffering animals. However, the last episode of Rublev's comeback to icon art is the ray of hope that is like a final reward for sufferings shown in the film. Thus, although the film has depressive realistic character, the ending of the film shows the sign of the hope both for Andrei and Russian people of that time.
For all episodes of the film, the viewer can see the death, torture, persecution faced by characters, therefore, to watch the film it is necessary to be prepared for the deep thinking. The Prologue shows the death of the Yefim in his attempt to fly on air-balloon. I think, this scene is the premise to the atmosphere of the whole film, describing the sadness the viewer will feel the following episodes. The first episode shows the lack of the freedom of speech through the skomorokh's arrest for his songs about boyars and monks, who turns out in last episodes will half of his tongue cut for this. In the next episodes, when Andrei and his teacher Theophanes discuss about the religion, we see the scene of the Crucifixion of Christ accompanied by touching and sad music .Also, the next episode called "Holiday" introduces very different from other episodes scene with naked pagans ritual which shows the world of temptation and pleasure and dialogue of Andrei with Marfa, one of pagan girls about love. This episode ends with the arrest of one of the pagans by soldiers, showing their lack of freedom in the expression of their faith and their truth of life.
The next episodes include more cruelty and torture faced by ordinary people from those who possess power. For instance, in the episode "The Last Judgment" artisans that refused to work on the Grand Duke's order and decide to work on his brother's order, get attacked and had eyes cut off. Or in the next episode of the Tatars' raid of Vladimir, when Grand Duke's brother helps to Tatars wishing for more power. I think, unlike all episodes, this raid particularly shows the hardships the commoners in Russia are facing, when they are betrayed by their Russian brothers headed by Grand Duke's brother, raped and killed by invaders. Also, this episode includes one of the most brutal scenes when invaders torture Patrikei the messenger, by pouring boiling mixture into his mouse, and tie his legs to a running horse. It is not an easy to watch fragment, however for this film this part was not accompanied by the emotional emphasis or other attributes, as if it was an ordinary action. Moreover, this episode shows how Rublev takes person's life in order to save the holy fool (Durochka). And this episode plays important role as Andrei's life as he loses things he appreciates: his helpers who get killed, and his innocence by killing a man, which in turn result in losing of his will to paint. The episode "Silence" shows the next phase of Rublev's life who lives more ascetic life keeping silence. Also, this episode informs about the famine people are facing. This way almost every episode of the film includes moments of torture and killing of people or animals, and while watching these scenes it can be seen the director did not put emphasis in most of these torture fragments. Probably, this way the director wanted to show that these sufferings were ordinary to the 15th century Russia.
However, despite all episodes showing this hardships and despair of Russians, by the last episode it is likely that the director wanted to show the light at the end of the tunnel both for Rublev and for Russian people through the bell construction. Boriska, son of the bellmaker who lost his family after the plague and stayed all alone, convinces the prince's people that his father told him the secret of making bells for church. After, he leads the group of workers and does his job without listening to others advices and feels very stressful and frightened. At the end of the work, the spectators of the film as well as the people in the film also are intrigued weather the bell will ring or not. Finally, when the bell rings, we can hear the sound of peoples' joy, and Boriska's relief. I think, this moment was one of the most powerful moments for the whole film; after all these sufferings, Boriska can let his tears out, while people could hear the voice of the bell reuniting all people in the ceremony. When Boriska was crying, Rublev who was observing how Boriska was struggling all this time, breaks his silence to calm Boriska down and decides to paint again. In this way, the talent of Boriska who casted a bell even when his father did not tell him its secret, had a strong impact on Andrei motivating him to return into art. Also, Andrei seeing Durochka in a veil with a horse also plays symbolic role in the film. Even though Andrei was worrying about her and his desire to protect her, other people convinced him that nobody will abuse God's fool in earlier episodes. And the fact that last scene of the episode was her face smiling proves those peoples' words. I think, because hurting God's fool is counted as a big sin, she was protected and lived in this world of suffering for all other people. This way director wanted to show this power of "holliness".
Moreover, the Epilogue of the film ends with Rublev's colorful paintings, the only colorful scenes in the film. I think, knowing the importance of iconic paintings in Orthodox Christianity after facing iconoclasm, this part shows the great legacy of these Christians showing the positive ending of the film resulting in Rublev's return to the art, leaving these works for generations.
In conclusion, although the start episodes of the film show the inner conflicts and seems like a sign of the unhopeful sadness, the end episode and Epilogue shows the power of the true talent and art that never dies.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films I have ever seen in my life.
reviews.content:
Andrei Tarkovsky makes a very good job depicting the life of monks and the political, cultural, and social environment surrounding them. His job shows that despite the process of the historical development of the society various facets of the Church's life tend to have features that can endure the centuries of change and historical development of the world. At first glance, it appears as a demonstration of the cruel and dirty nitty-gritty in Medieval Russia. However, the situation is more complex. Through the demonstration of monks' life, particularly Andrei Rublev, the author shows different facets of Christianity which can be seen through the actions of the main characters.
The work of Andrei Tarkovsky reflects numerous features of Christianity. Even the beginning of the film reflects one of the major characteristics of the Church, namely strictness and conservatism. At the beginning of the film, a couple of men are trying to launch a flying device from the top of the Church and their efforts are being stopped by the intervention of some unidentified men (possibly monks or warriors). However, they successfully launch the flying device into the air. It may seem to just only reflect the conservatism of the Church that hindered technological and scientific progress. The true meaning is much deeper than it may seem. Unidentified men (probably monks or warriors), who unsuccessfully try to prevent the launch of the flying device symbolize the Church which tries to make religion more rigid, ordered, and codified. It tolerates no deviation. The men who are trying to launch the flying bulb, in turn, symbolize the various heretics (Arians, Nestorians, Monophysites). This scene shows the repressive role of the Church which using ecumenical councils repressed the various deviations from Orthodox Christianity. For example, the first ecumenical council condemned Arianism, the third ecumenical council resulted in a schism with Nestorian Church and the fourth ecumenical council condemned monophysite heresy ("Christian Schisms"). The persecution of those who want to launch the flying bulb is analogous to the persecution of heretics in the previous centuries and this scene reflects Christianity's tendency to show zero tolerance to those who don't accept mainstream beliefs. To sum up, we analyzed the similarity between the persecution of men launching the flying device with the persecution of various heresies by the Church.
Another interesting aspect of Tarkovsky's work is the argument between different attitudes towards Christianity and its social implications. Humans are a very important subject of discussion in every religion including Christianity. In the film, Theophanes the Greek (the famous icon painter) and Andrei Rublev have different perspectives on the nature of evil and humanity. According to Theophanes the Greek, humans are innately bad, driven by fear, and humans and the world do not change. At the same time, Andrei Rublev questions the point of view of Theophanes and claims that humans are victims of ignorance. What can be the reason for such different views on the natures of humans and sin? They both have different backgrounds and origins. Theophanes the Greek grow up in the Byzantine Empire and studied there. Andrei Rublev grow up and studied in Moscow principality. Their different background resulted in different attitudes. This is similar to the controversy between the Greek Orthodox Church and the Coptic Church. Greek Orthodox Church had support in urban areas and Greek upper class ("Christian Schisms"). Whilst the Coptic Church dominated the area along the Nile river ("Christian Schisms"). This different social background resulted in differences in certain religious questions in the case of Orthodox Christians and Copts too. To summarize, this film reflects how a difference in the social background shapes the differences in religious views.
The controversy between Churches can exist on a deeper level resulted from schism. This schism can be reflected by the relationships between monks in the film. These monks are Kirill and Andrei. Kirill was not so talented and tried to become assistant of Theophanes the Greek using sycophancy. He envied Andrei Rublev's talent and tried to give bad feedback on him. Finally, after some time messenger arrives at the monastery and tells that Andrei Rublev, not Kirill is invited. Kirill initiates a scandal and accuses everyone of greed. However, his envy was not the only reason for conflict between him and Andrei. Another source of conflict is his dissatisfaction with himself, with his lack of talent. These numerous factors resulting in conflict between Kirill and Andrei show the similarity between Great Schism and conflict between Andrei and Kirill. There also were numerous reasons, like changes in the Nicene Creed, the question of Papal supremacy, the question of celibate versus married priesthood, the question of what bread should be eaten during the communion leavened or unleavened that resulted in Great Schism ("Christian Schisms"). Similarly to the envy and dissatisfaction of Kirill, they finally culminated in a Schism in 1054. So, Andrei Tarkovsky artfully shows break up between Kirill and Andrei symbolizing the Great Schism.
In his genius work, Andrei Tarkovsky demonstrates various aspects of the Christian religion. He shows the rigid and repressive character of the Church which tolerates no deviation from mainstream religion. Another aspect of Christianity that is shown is the influence of different backgrounds on the religious views of different people. Andrei Tarkovsky also successfully demonstrates how a complex of controversies results in break-up or Schism. To conclude, Andrei Tarkovsky successfully shows different aspects of Christianity in his film.

To me, this movie wasn't really boring at all. Some scenes seemed to misguided, but overall the movie had a pretty good flow. Solaris was boring as hell, with shots that just hang there forever. Why? Rublev has some amazing camera wizardry that kept the story interesting. The disconnected structure was good to paint an overall portrait of an age. The movie brilliantly captures and creates a despairing mural of a time and place that seems to have been amazingly cruel and harsh. This is one of those movies, like the Godfather, that creates its own little universe. We rarely question the authenticity of the settings or characters because it all feels so real. The main charcter could have been explored or externalized a bit more, i thought. There are many scenes where we're not really sure what he's thinking. Not sure why he's doing what he's doing. This gives the movie a kind of floating dreamlike quality that kind of mesmerizes you.      But the film has its share of awesome violence, like during the Tartar raid. How some of these scenes where directed I don't know, but they are amazing examples of Tarkovsky's versatility in handling material. He navigates between thunderous attack and quiet reflection so smoothly the movie is rarely jarring in the usual way. A hollywood movie would be edited for maximum dramatic impact, whereas the terror in these scenes builds up gradually. For me, the singular image of the movie is the young squire being shot in the back with an arrow and slowly collapsing into the stream. That scene is one the most disturbing things i've seen in a movie. It's rendered beautifully, quiet and solemn.

This movie is one brilliant film The cinematography is breathtaking The acted is carried out to perfection and the story itself is moving and beautiful I was near tears after watching the first ten minutes of this film. Contrary to some opinions, every section of the movie is absorbing and necessary.'Andrei Rublyov' is captivating and a wonderful film. It is no wonder that it is near the top on many film scholars' 'Top Ten' Lists.

It's not a biography by any means, it's largely fiction - it's only loosely based off Rublev's life. The film focuses more on his dedication to Eastern Orthodoxy, as well as its role in his evolution as an artist. There are certain characters that each represent different philosophical outlooks under a single unanimous religious belief. In particular, Theophanes is an interesting take on someone being God-loving yet simultaneously overly cynical in his repulsion by His man's vile nature. Outside of characters, the story is alright. The second half is mostly boring in my opinion. Being shot in black and white to emphasize the colorful ending - no doubt to add "life" to the conclusion - is kind of gimmicky, but otherwise a decent film.
