Within the handful of films that I count as influential in my life, this masterpiece by Tarkovsky is in that list.  This was my introduction to Russian cinema.  I have since seen and fell in love with other works by Tarkovsky.  He was a master of the art, at the level of Kurosawa.  This is not just a movie, it is a living work of visual poetry in motion, that will touch you at a depth few film-makers will ever reach.

It is difficult to begin even describing the impact and beauty of this film. It is the only film I would ever want to review, and it is my first and only review on imdb for a reason. Having seen Andrei Rublev and closely studied it, shot by shot, scene for scene after 7 years, I can only come to the conclusion this is without a doubt, the greatest film ever made... I could go on for hours on end to describe why each scene is perfect, sublime, how no director has managed to block a film like this where every composition, every frame, is more engrossing than the previous-to orchestrate such scenes of grandeur and also ones of divine simplicity... So great is this film's impact, that if one takes the time to truly feel and know this film, any other cinematic experience pales in comparison. Tarkovsky here, is treating cinema as a means to spiritual and religious enlightenment, an epiphany, one might dare say even a gospel. He should be treated as a Michelangelo, a Tolstoy or a Dostoyevsky. Andrei Rublev is to cinema, what War & Peace or the Brothers Karamazov is to literature, what Beethoven's 9th is to music-to compare it to cinema in the traditional sense (e.g. Hitchcock) doesn't make any sense. If any one film, could bring you closer to God, closer to realising the futility of all human pettiness and ambition, this is it.Never have I seen greater performances by an entire ensemble perfectly cast and in complete control of their craft completely lost in their roles, no other filmmaker has shown such technical and narrative skill and inspiration in every turn, eons beyond their years, perfectly complementing his story and actors, elevating the film to divinity with every minor stroke-the "lone tree scene" alone has to be the most beautifully realised and executed scene put on celluloid, revealing the passage of time and decay, the very notion of remembrance and love itself, like no other-exalted with a few simple notes on the Glockenspiel-the only sign of modernity in the film besides the ending, as if Tarkovsky is pleading with us to comprehend the timelessness of our lives, when life draws to a close. This scene, crucial to the entire film, which might be missed by many in a first viewing, besides being cinema at its truest and sublimest form, encompasses the essence of what Tarkovsky is trying to say in this film... That when all is said and done, we can at least try to remember with love, the people who we crossed paths with and the life we had... that we forgave and were forgiven and only love remains in our remembrance (as per the hymn of love).Or the lingering shot of Cyril, as he looks at Andrei Rublev for the last time, having confessed his life-long envy, you can see in the mans eyes, acknowledgement that Andrei will make it, he will succeed in making his mark in time, that they have both forgiven one another, and can now meet again in better terms in eternity, that he is even proud of him-without a single word exchanged by Andrei. I can't think of a more genius way, of saying so much with so little. Never have such feelings been better portrayed in any art form. No artist has ever better encapsulated the human struggle with jealousy, cruelty, hatred, war and the futility of all human endeavours outside love and God's word (it is no coincidence we find Paul's hymn of love before the true war and cruelty begins, right in the middle of the film with the only scene including children-royal children by no coincidence)... The entire film, plays as Andrei Tarkovsky has directed it, as a grande testament, a pleading, for us to see through the profane, to plod through it in search of the sacred. This is a film, where every scene, every small detail, will remain with you for the rest of your life, if only you give it the attention and respect it deserves. Like a few other reviewers have commented, this film could very easily nearly destroy cinema for you. Nothing, can simply compare.What is truly sad, though, is that so few filmmakers have tried to follow a spiritual calling through film and treat it as a pure art-form, beyond entertainment and prestige and red-carpets (which Tarkovsky hated), this is a film of true humility in an art-form that seems to have lost any sense of it, if it every fully grasped for an extended period of time in the first place... Many contemporary attempts have been made, but they fail to realise the humility required, the very sacrifice of ones self (as Tarkovsky advocated in "Voyage in Time") to their art, and what one has to go through if they want to receive grace... This film is the most moving love letter to ones fellow man...And to those who have criticised this film and its director, for being self-indulgent and pretentious, I wonder if they would think the same of Tolstoy or Dostoyevsky for not writing popular literature. Tarkovsky strived, to treat film and the cinematic language as it truly is, an art form not a means of mass consumption, and in a sense with hindsight one can see that he was and still is somewhat hated for this. He didn't make a political cinema, or follow the zeitgeist of his time and its agendas, and thus he was an exile, figuratively and literally...As a filmmaker myself, there are so many films I adore and so many filmmakers who changed my life, first and foremost Kurosawa, as well as Bresson, Fellini, Visconti, Bergman, Kieslowski, Truffaut and so many others... and I am no stranger to other cinematic approaches and languages, and I think cinema requires great diversity, but this film truly, in my humble opinion beats them all... it reaches the realm of the divine.

Russian state at the beginning of the XV century. The country is torn apart by different ruling elites of regions. Tatars' raids, famine and epidemy are pursuing the people. In this tragic period, a great icon painter appears in Russia, the plot of the picture is fully dedicated to the life and fate of the legendary Andrei Rubilov. He is an itinerant monk, traveling around Russia and observing life and human morals. Information about him is scarce and sketchy. Nevertheless, the filmmakers sought to recreate the spiritual world of Andrei Rubilov. 
The film carries a lot of deep meaning and gives the atmosphere to everything that happens. At the early beginning of the picture simple Russian men think of a flight. Despite the obscurity in the country, oppression of free thinking, people are living a creative life. One interesting point, on the boat to the place where ball is built in a hurry the man Yefim sails. His first words: "Come quickly, hurry up!" In my point of view, these guys clearly know that what they do is strictly persecuted and forbidden. Nevertheless, they do their job, and the ball, despite the sailing archers, flies quite well. Yefim flies over the fields, rivers. He opens the boundless landscape of the Russian land. Yefim laughs, laughs like a child - he is embraced by joy, a sense of freedom. 
The filmmaker beautifully depicts the image and transmission of the life of the peasants, where at any moment the scene can be joyful, and it can be sad. The movie is divided into five chapters, first of them entitled "Skomoroh" or in other words "holiday" and introduces us into the joyful life of the peasants with their songs with traditional dances and humor. At that time moment Andrei Rubilov confronted the Tatar raid on the city of Vladimir, they severely destroy the facilities and oppress the Russian people. Experiencing the true tragedy and deep moral crisis in XV century Russia Andrei Rubilov fell into deep concern how to withstand all this kind of turmoil and how to turn the people's mind and make them a little more moral. 
That scene and moral sufferings of Andrei Rubilov is beautifully shown in the chapter entitled "Passion according to Andrei." For certain time of moment legendary painter could not find his true passion, and frequently questioning his true talent - is this God gift or this is illusion? Generally asserting, this chapter includes all the main ideas that are important for understanding the work and aspiration of Andrei Rubilov, why he is striving to attain his life goals and what is the price of his all these sufferings for moral virtue. Eternal thoughts about good and evil, sin and God, disgusting qualities of humankind such as cruelty and immorality are all the part of this section of the movie. Despite these all turmoil situation in Russia, Andrei Rubilov shows his true love toward a Russian people and land, which in its he shows his consent to endure all confusions just in order to preserve the Russian identity. Indeed, the filmmaker by this passage delivers to us the true moral of a successful human existence which only could become possible through true love and enduring all the hardships in the name of maintaining your nations identity and land. 
During such hardship times Russian people seek to help from God, as I mentioned before in order to sustain their national identity and land. However, the scene with the invasion of Tatars is the apogee of showing godlessness, cruelty and greediness of Russian people, and it shows why Russian people seek help from God only when they had experienced turmoil. Andrei Rubilov does not stand aside during this hardship period of Russian history, he helps people to turn their faith toward God and morality through his works such as icon painting. 
At the last section of the movie, the cast bell plays significant symbolic importance. The joy of his ringing in people symbolizes, even a temporary, but still true connection of Russian people with God during the hardships. In my perspective, by the construction of huge bell want to show the greatness and unity of man with God. From the movie director's perspective, it seems to me that regardless of how hard it would be, no matter what awaits a person on his life's journey, human's faith to God would definitely help him to overcome trails at any moment and therefore, the unity of person with God is the meaning of life. 
To conclude, this movie in religious perspectives very simple and at the same time complex, meaningful picture, imbued with humanism and love towards your nation and your motherland. The film accurately conveying the spirit of the age and the spirit of Andrei Rubilov, and his quest for moral virtue. Moreover, the picture amazingly portrayed the controversial world called as unity with God and humankind's own destiny.

reviews.review_title: Piece of philosophical and historical cinematography for a limited audience
reviews.content:
"Andrei Rublev" is a great philosophical and historical piece of cinematography that not only depicts the events and mentality of that time but also touches upon the theme of the inner fight of a human in regards to faith and his place in the world.
One of the strengths of the movie is the fact that it is full of meaningful symbolism, which intertwines with the tragic history of medieval Russia to create multi-layered conflict. An example of that symbolism can be the opening scene of the movie that allows us to fully view the sacred space of Russian Christianity - the Orthodox Church. According to well-known philosopher Eliade, sacred space is a space that was endowed with a special purpose in religion, the place that represents it. This way, the Orthodox Church in "Andrei Rublev" becomes the symbol of the abated faith when we see the inability of the church as a space to protect parishioners from the attacks of Tatar-Mongol Yoke.
Another strength of the movie is the beauty of the cinematic picture that can express the atmosphere and identity of Russian medieval culture. Dark and long shots create a unique feeling to the events and dialogues that are demonstrated on the screen. However, these two main strengths of Tarkovsky's "Andrei Rublev" can push away some of the audience since a high level of symbolism and long shots can be considered as unnecessary and unrelieved in terms of the plot. This is also a reason for a movie to be considered as a piece of such genre as "arthouse" which usually consists of the pictures created for a limited audience.
The writing is another strong component of the movie since we can witness thoroughly written character development that Andrey undergoes during twenty-four years. This character development from a conflicted sufferer to a strong and magnanimous artist that brings a bright message to people through his art of interpretations of religious concepts - the art of iconography.
The direction and acting in the movie are also of high quality. The scenes and their order in the plot are designed to create a sense of immersion with the atmosphere of the movie and the feelings of the characters among the audience. Tarkovsky's unique and audacious methods of narration were able to capture my attention from the beginning to the ending of the movie despite the long shots.
To conclude, it can be said that "Andrei Rublev" by Tarkovsky is a unique piece of cinematography that emerged from the convergence of Soviet and medieval Russian mentalities to raise philosophical questions of fate and religion. Despite the fact that the movie can be considered unbearable and unnecessarily pretentious because of the peculiarities of the style of its director, Tarkovsky was able to reach the minds of people in many ways, including historical and religiously existential.

The film illustrates not only about the life of the famous icon painter, but more about the sorrow of a man, who went through all the suffering in the name of a goal, in the name of his faith. Despite the popularity of the artist, his biography remains mysterious, which gave almost limitless space for the imagination of the Producer. Before moving on to the personality of Andrey Rublyov himself, at the beginning it is worth noting the bravery of the Director: the film contains plenty scenes of nudity, illustration of the paganism with ceremonies, and in general, it was probably the first film about the Orthodox faith and religion in the censored and atheistic USSR. First of all, the film is sad, filled with pain and suffering, and this is not only the pain of the main character, it is the pain of the entire population, the pain of that time. Hunger, dirt, fear and the invasion of the Tatars do not allow the ordinary population to simply live as a human, it ruins also the souls of people who are greedily looking for peace. And the black and white footage only adds to the film only sorrow.
The main thesis of the film is that faith plays the most important role in people's lives: it leads people to success, to a good life, and those who do not have it continue to live in suffering.
Andrey Rublyov from immature man turns into a real thinker, trying to comprehend the tormenting questions of existence. He sees completely unpleasant people, sees that evil has spread around. He is disappointed, broken. He is concerned about what is happening to people. And besides, he has big internal problems. He understands that he cannot create because he does not believe in the sincerity of the people who come to pray, nor in his own sincerity. He cannot touch the sacred, because in his soul there is a struggle and a doubt.
At times, Andrey Rublyov is tormented by a choice: on the one hand, Church laws, on the other - social justice. He understands that the dumb fool is a sinner and violates the laws, but can she be punished? He saves her by committing a terrible crime - murder. Andrey makes his choice, he feels that he can't get away from people, get away from them. And this is a big step towards the true faith that he will find later.
Probably the most powerful, but at the same time the most understandable novel of the film is "the Bell". Boriska, in order not to be alone, in order not to starve to death without food, lies, mentioning that he knows the secret of casting the bell and began to work. However, what does he have in his soul and mind? Only faith and nothing more. The novel illustrates the power of the strong faith. Boriska has put his whole life on it: he constructs the bell, or he will be punished or die. When the bell is cast, when it rings, there is powerful moral, spiritual, and religious revolution takes place with both Andrey and Boriska. Boriska is crying and sobbing. He truly felt God. How could a young guy who didn't know anything about the art of bell casting made a perfect bell? He had laid down his life on one faith and gained far more than he could have imagined.
For Andrey, this is also moment of change in his soul and mind. He sees that the people who blaspheme and sin, now, at the sight of a miracle are in a wonderful, joy mood. Smiles on their faces, and joy fills their souls, and they remember what love is. Andrew understands that no matter how angry the people are, they must be believed in, because if a person like Andrew must believe in them. It is necessary to create for the benefit of people, for the happiness and joy of people, so that they feel love. Andrey understands that his vocation is icon painting. He must perform this moral, spiritual, and religious actions. "Here we go with you, Boriska. You cast the bell; I draw the icons".
Through the life of the main character Andrey, or Boriska, or even the entire population of Medieval Rus, it proves that faith played the most important role in their lives. "Art exists only because this world is poorly organized." With these words, the Producer tried to convey to viewers that artists (painters), similar to any other creators, work on their labor in order to bring at least a drop of beauty to this imperfect, filled with gray (like the movie itself) colors of the world. Art exists because people need hope and faith. The belief that not everything in this world is colored with gray. The confidence that one day everything in life, like the final picture, will spill out in color.

reviews.review_title: An epic tour through medieval life and art
reviews.content: I first saw Andrei Rublyov when I was a teenager in a late night TV showing of one of the longer versions.  I was transported, and those three hours gave me a deeper understanding of medieval life than all my school history lessons.Tarkovsky manages to mix tiny details of everyday life, desperate tragedies, deep theological arguments and huge historical events into one epic story. The film remains one of my all-time favourites.
